It is possible your weight mutation strength is too high or too 
low.  You may want to try capping max weights also.  Weight 
mutations can sometimes be a problem with XOR.

Also, before you do anything else, you should hand-construct a 
solution (including the right weights) and run it through your 
activation function to make sure it works.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "John Arrowwood" <jarrowwx@h...> wrote:
> And it is adequately fast.  XOR is fully Perl based, and does a 
generation 
> with a population size of 100 at a rate of about 5-6 per second.  
Fast 
> enough to not bore me, anyway.
> 
> I've added more configurable items, and I've tested it enough to 
make sure 
> it behaves as I expected it to.  And it does.  Problem is, it 
doesn't solve 
> XOR.  The best solution is structured as I would expect:  one 
hidden node.  
> The output node is connected to all input and bias and hidden, and 
the 
> hidden is connected to all input and bias.  00 returns 0.11, 01 
and 10 
> return 0.99, but 11 returns 1.0!  ug...
> 
> Maybe I am killing off the stagnant species too fast?  Or maybe I 
need to 
> use a non-linear penalty function...  have the penalty kick in as 
it nears 
> the end.  I'll do some more experimenting.
> 
> In the mean time, anybody have any tips for me?  Are 
there 'issues' 
> surrounding XOR that I should know about?  Parameters that if 
aren't set 
> correctly render it impossible to find a solution?
